titleStmt.title: Newgates Garland a New Ballade
giving an Account how B\ins·l\lueskin the
bold Highway-man cut Ionathan Wilds

publicationStmt.p: Distributed by Digital Scholarship Services at Lafayette College

lg.l: Swift
Ye Fellows of Newgate whose fingers are nice
In diving in Pockets and cogging of Dice
Ye Sharpers so rich who can buy off yẹ noose
Ye honest poor Rogues that insdie in your ShoesAttend & draw nearGood news you shall hear
How Ionathans throat was ins cut from Ear to Ear
How Blueskin's sharp Penknife has set us at ease
And every man round me may rob if he please
When to the old Bayly this Blueskin was led
He held up his hand his Indictment was read
Loud rattled his chains near him Ionathan stood
For full 40 Pounds whas yẹ price of his BloddTheinsn hopeless of lifeHe drew his Penknife
And made a sad widow of Ionathans wife
But 40 pounds paid her grief will appease
And every man round me may rob if he please
Some say there are Courtiers of highest renown
Who steal the Kings gold & leave him but a Crown
Some Say there are Peers & some Parliament men
Who meet once a year to rob Courtiers againLet them all take a swingWho pillage the King
And get a blue garter instead of a String
For Blueskins sharp penknife &c̣
Knaves of old to hide guilt by cunning inventions
Call'd bribery's──Grants & plain robbery's Pensions
Pysicians and Lawyers (who take their degrees)
To insbe learned Rogues) call their pilferings──FeesSince this hapy dayNow every one may
Rob (as safe as in Office) upon yẹ highway
For Blueskins sharp penknife &c̣
Some cheat in the Customs some rob the Excise
And he who robs both is esteemed most wise
Churchwardens who always have dreaded yẹ halter
As yet only venture to steal from yẹ AlterBut now to get goldThey may be more bold
And rob on the Highway since Jonathans cold
For Blueskins sharp penknife &c̣
Some by publick Revenues which pass thro' their hands
Have purchas'd clean Houses and bṭ dirty lands
Some to steal from a Charity think it no sin
Which at home (says yẹ Proverb) does always beginBut ever you beAssign'd a Trustee
Treat nor Orphans like Masters of Chancery
But take the Highway & more honestly seize
And every man round me may rob if he please
What a Pother has here been wtḥ Wood & his Brass
Who wou'd modestly make a few halfpennies pass
That Patent is good and yẹ President old
For Diomede chang'd his Copper for goldBut if Ireland despiseThe new halfpennies
With more safety to rob on yẹ road I advise
For Blueskins sharp penknife has set us at ease
And every man round me may rob if he pleaseY13-655B
